ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Pre-recorded video lectures.
Lectures for this class were smaller sections, and then we had asynchronous videos to watch as well before each class.
Live virtual classes with supplementary recorded lectures that went along with the textbook readings.
n/a
There were also pre-class recorded lectures to watch as well as pre-class quizzes that we took.
Included recorded pre-class videos
Virtual non recorded lecture
recordings before class
Live discussion sections.
A smaller lecture style with breakout rooms
Recorded lectures and live virtual lectures.

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Developed knowledge in multivariable calculus as well as problem solving skills for problems in multi.
I think this course gave me a comprehensive understanding of multivariable calculus, building on the Calculus I and Calculus II.

I learned the foundations of multi-variable calculus, three dimensional reasoning and visualizing, integrating in multiple dimensions with both vector and scalar quantities, and a series of theorems that relate quantities of differing dimensions--Green's Theorem, Stokes' Theorem, and Divergence theorem among others.
I learned a lot about multivariable calculus.
Vector functions and vector calculus, double and triple integrals, calculus of 3D objects

Math 120 definitely taught me a lot about multivariable calculus, with a particular emphasis on interpreting the various calculations. It also taught me that math is frequently hard, and pushed me to persevere more through the tricky problems.
Calculus of two to three variables.
I learned how to think critically. I learned a lot of mathematical concepts which can be transferred over to physics, advanced economics, and many other disciplines.

I learned many multivariable theorems and operations and also learned how to recognize which of these to use to solve various problems. I also learned to recognize which methods of solving a problem were most effective depending on the problem. Finally, I also got better at visualizing surfaces in 3 dimensional space as well as accepting 4 dimensional objects, despite the human inability to visualize them.
QR skills and problem solving.
Multivariable calculus basics.
Thinking of math in a more applied sense
An excellent thorough understanding of multivariable calculus and basic vector calculus. 3d spaces, iterative integrals, change of coordinate system, div/grad/curl, Green's and Stoke's theorems.
Problem-solving and abstract mathematical thinking.
I learned how to apply mathematics concepts to some real world examples and how to critically think to solve math problems.
Partial derivatives, gradients, curl, vector fields, line integrals, surface integrals, Green/Stokes/Gauss's Theorem

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strengths:
Easy to follow lecture and assignments.
Great promotion of group work and learning/application assessments.

Weaknesses:
Somewhat unwelcoming learning environment.

I think the course was designed very carefully with pre-lecture quizzes and videos. However, at points I felt like I didn't understand the material enough to do the pre-lecture quizzes, yet the content we covered in class always helped me clear up the points I didn't initially understand.

I found that this course did an excellent job of focusing on our conceptual understanding and unifying themes and principles throughout the semester. We did a lot of geometric reasoning and 3D visualizations to aid our understanding, and the material was explained at a pace which really worked well for me. With regards to exams, there were plenty of review materials made available and overall review sessions which were excellent at covering the month's worth of content. 
Something I found a bit frustrating were the comprehension quizzes before class. Occasionally, I wouldn't quite understand a concept the first time around, and I felt penalized for it by the reading quiz. Granted, they were worth a small portion of our grade, but it was still something that frustrated me.
The course was interesting and very informative.
The lectures weren't very engaging and the problem sets were super hard. Also the course moves way too fast so you don't really learn as much.

The pre-class videos were definitely helpful in getting a fundamental knowledge about the topics at hand, but I often found that then lecture sections were repetitive of the same fundamentals in the videos. I would've liked to see some more complex applications within lecture. I think the smaller sections help for this difficult course material to be more approachable. Problem sets are definitely useful in preparing students for assessments, but I think the gap in difficulty between the examples in lecture and the problems in problem sets was a little much.

The recorded lectures that went with the readings were very helpful in summarizing the reading and working through examples. We also had a great instructor who was very passionate and engaging in live sessions. However, sometimes it seems that the recorded lectures and live sessions were redundant as we would cover the same idea again in class.

A strength is that there is a good balance between providing you with enough information to be able to the psets and making you actually think and struggle with the problems at the same time. A weakness might be that class was sometime a regurgitation of the textbook.

I believe that the course was very clear about what material students needed to learn and what concepts would be tested on. The problem sets prepared me well for exams. However, I believe that the course could be improved by doing more practice problems during class and less lecturing. This is because the pre-class pre-recorded lectures are already very comprehensive and sufficient to learn the material, but a lot of those concepts got repeated too much during class.
This class was amazing! I really liked the pre-class videos and how lectures could be used to cover theoretical material instead of going over the basic concepts.
I liked having breakout rooms to work on problems in class.
review of pset like questions as examples in lecture

This course was not taught well. I had a lot of difficulty understanding the material and there was little help or assistance beyond my fellow classmates who struggled with me. It feels like you are constantly grasping for a bare-minimum understanding that is still not enough to make you come out of the course feeling satisfied with what you have learned about multivariable calculus. Most of the students I know who did not struggle as much as I did have already taken a multivariable course in high school. If you have never learned multivariable calculus before, Math 120 will be extremely tough and challenging. It will be difficult to find and seek help, especially with online learning.

The course is organized very well. The biweekly lectures were highly informative and provided a great place to ask questions and see worked examples. Problem sets were manageable but challenging, and midterms were excellently written and graded.
There should be a final exam and students should be allowed to drop their lowest exam grade.

A major strength of the course was the small format. Having fewer people in my class meant more direct engagement. I also appreciated the vast amount of resources outside of class, including the lecture videos and notes.

Strengths were that the teachers were all very helpful. A weakness was that the recorded lectures did not allow for questions to be asked in the moment which might have been forgotten by the time class came.

I liked the variety of different resources. You could learn the course material through the lectures, reading the textbook, or the pre-class recordings, and they all supplemented each other to reinforce the concepts. There wasn't much more to ask for, although I would have appreciated pdf notes of the important concepts/formulas.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I think having polls and interactive break-out rooms in zoom helped us become more engaged and understand the material better.
Generally speaking, the Zoom instruction was pretty good all things considered. Trying to simulate groupwork with breakout sessions was very appreciated.
The pre-class modules were very helpful.
The peer tutoring hours could've been improved.
I liked the smaller virtual sections, they helped me in being able to ask questions and get individual feedback.

I really enjoyed it when the professor would go over examples in class, as it helped develop the topics from the readings. The breakout rooms often were not very productive, as no one would talk with each other and just try to work on the problems alone due to the virtual setting.
Breakout rooms definitely forced you to be engaged. I would say that it might be smart not to schedule the final midterm around move out period.
I like how my professor incorporated random breakout rooms into most of the lectures, which allowed me to meet other math 120 students and talk to a variety of people.

The pre-class videos quite helpful. I also liked how my professor tried to stimulate engagement during the actual lecture. I wish that the actual lecture was recorded though - it would have been helpful for when I was having technical difficulties and was unable to get on.
Breakout rooms was useful.
I believe it went as well as possible in light of the pandemic

My professor did not record lectures, which made things extremely difficult because I could never go back and rewatch a lecture if I was confused on something. You are expected to understand material from the first time that it is taught. Although resources like the textbook are available, it still would have been extremely helpful to have recorded lectures. There also are no discussion sections that I think would have been beneficial to go through example problems together, considering that any practice problems done during lectures were not recorded. Overall, the course was frustrating to go through and extremely challenging. There was not much about this course that I would say "succeeded," other than perhaps the stimulating questions on problem sets that made you realize that you did not understand the material.

Math 120 is an excellent remote course. Lectures were wonderful, and most strikingly, remote midterms ran like clockwork. Every potential problem was accounted for, and the proctoring rooms were perfectly organized and executed. I did not encounter any problems during this course (unlike some other courses with remote exams).
I think the live lectures succeeded as they were very helpful but the recorded lectures and mini quizzes could have been better because they were not always very engaging.
The use of both pre-class videos and lectures were very effective.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
During the pandemic, this course is not meant for a student who is unfamiliar with concepts in multivariable calculus. Under normal circumstances, when help is more easily found and in person, I'm sure it then would be fine to go in headfirst and inexperienced. 

This course is meant for students looking to refresh or consolidate knowledge of multi.
I would recommend this course only if you have a very strong background in Calculus I and Calculus II, as many of my classmates already had a basic understanding of multivariable concepts.

If the topics of the class interest you, or if you have to as a prereq, I would recommend taking it. The concepts really flow together into an unified understanding, and I think it's provides a valuable mathematical foundation that is broadly applicable. While it might seem daunting, the class is set up to help you succeed with many an office hour and review session. I can speak for every person or professor, but I thought my professor (Professor Adelstein) was very good at explaining the material and more than willing to help students out. The PSETs were tough, but working collaboratively on them makes it much more doable.
I would recommend this course because I learned a lot about the topics in multivariable calculus.
No unless you need it for a prereq. If you're doing engineering, I would recommend ENAS 151 instead
Take Math 120 if you really want to learn calculus or if you need this for your major.
Yes, because the topics we learned are very interesting and seem highly versatile and applicable to other disciplines.
Definitely a good math course for people who have already taken BC. Will definitely help with other harder classes.

I would recommend this course to another student. The instructions and expectations were very clear and the professors are all very open to answering student questions and concerns; they encourage more questions. Furthermore, the professors are very fun to get to know outside of class (which we accomplished this year through small group zoom meetings). However, the class curriculum is no doubt challenging at times, and I would not recommend the class if the student is not willing to lay down a couple of hours of time throughout the week to truly work through and understand the concepts in the problem sets.
I would recommend this course to all students, because calculus is very fun and is something all people should have the opportunity to do.
Yes, it is a good class for introduction to multivariable calculus.
No. Not unless you have to. Stay away from math 120.
Yes because it makes you think mathematically in a new way

No, but unfortunately, this is one of the few introductory multivariable calculus courses that Yale has to offer. You may not have a choice, but it is rewarding in the idea that once the course ends, you can claim that you have completed Math 120.

Yes, definitely! I would recommend to anyone who has either taken MV their senior year of high school and wants a refresher or has taken BC calc and feels ready for an engaging, challenging introduction to multivariable.
I would, as it delves deep into real-life mathematical applications around calculus and enhances the student's problem-solving and mathematical thinking.

This course is usually required for many STEM majors and pre-meds; there are probably more engaging and stimulating courses out there (like MATH 230). However, I still learned quite a lot and I would recommend it for any student interested in math that isn't necessarily at a higher level.
I would recommend this course to anyone who is studying stem as it is very interesting and gives a good foundation for lots of multivariable concepts.

This course is a required pre-req for many majors. Additionally, it introduces many fundamental ideas related to calculus that could be helpful for many students. Additionally, the course is designed so that it doesn't require too much advanced single-variable calculus knowledge (e.g. BC Calculus) so I was able to do well despite being rusty on those topics.
